utterances: Thank you.
And let us know, well, which of the big candidates have you managed to get an interview with as far?
Fred Thompson, Rudy Giuliani, John Edwards, Mitt Romney, Barack Obama, and that's it.
And that's it.
So that's still pretty good.
I can hear Ken Rudin gnashing his teeth as the National Public Radio sometimes can't get interviews with some of these people.
And I've also interviewed Elizabeth Edwards, Kevin Bacon, John Thompson and Bill Clinton.
What did Kevin Bacon have to say?
Well, I asked him why he was supporting John Edwards, and he said because he thinks he'd make a great president and lead the, you know…
Lead the country pretty well.
Lead the country to a better life.
And who is the most interesting person you've managed to speak with, thus far?
Probably Zach Johnson.
Zach Johnson and why?
Because he had a lot to say in about the Masters and stuff.
About the Masters.
So that's what you wanted to talk to, about golf?
A what?
About golf you mean.
I'm sorry, what?
What was he talking about?
The Masters?
Yeah.
Yeah, okay.
And so, to some degree, some of the sidekicks are more interesting than the candidates themselves?
Yes.
All right.
The other question I wanted to ask you is why did you get interested in politics at such a young age?
Because I wanted to learn more about stuffs - reporting and about all the candidates in case they - because one of them will be president.
Because one of them will be president.
Let me ask you of this, have you started collecting campaign buttons yet?
Mm-hmm.
Yes, you have.
Is she married?

That's Ken Rudin asking.
That's Sydney Rieckhoff.
Do you think you're going to follow this as a career later in life?
Yes.
All right.
A little competition for you, Ken, if we decide to go younger for our demographic.
Sydney, good luck to you in your reporting fro Scholastic Magazine.
Thank you.
Sydney Rieckhoff, one of the youngest, if not the youngest, political reporters on the campaign trail today, age 9, with us by phone from her home in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.
Nice to know that there's people coming up behind you, Ken.

This, again, going back to the question of have you gone to Iowa or New Hampshire to campaign?

Yes, it is.
Okay.
Go ahead.
Actually, not quite sure with New Hampshire, I am, since I'm not from area.
I came up a couple of - about a week ago.
I'm actually in Manchester apparently (unintelligible) decided to campaign for Ron Paul once I heard that there was a good movement there.
And an engineer from Google, actually, left this job in California and went all the way to New Hampshire and started a grass roots movement so I decided to join in.
And you're from New Haven, is that right?
No, I'm actually from Washington, D.C.
and I took a couple of weeks off during the Christmas holidays to come up here and campaign.
So the holidays worked out for you in that respect because you could -it turns out to be a crucial part of the campaign?
Exactly with the primaries (unintelligible) soon.
It actually worked out (unintelligible).
And why Ron Paul?

Really, I think he was the only candidate who represents my views and all of the views of many of my colleagues and friends, and also that not many people know about him since he's not covered that well in the TV and print media.
So we have to go door-to-door and spread his message and we've been pretty fortunate so far…
And…
…in New Hampshire where people are very open-minded and like to listen to you.
And will you be heartbroken if he loses?
Of course, I'll be heartbroken if he loses, as so many supporter of any candidate should be.

But we got our high hopes up and, especially after talking with people here and hearing their responses being very positive that, you know, ever day we get more and more confident that we're doing something pretty great here.
All right.
Well, good luck.
